subject: Management
title: Finding Common Ground
description: A quick, practical guide to Finding Common Ground.

hook.text: Sales wanted speed. Engineering wanted quality. They seemed like opposites. But both wanted happy customers.

buildup.text: In most conflicts, opposing positions hide shared underlying interests.

discovery.text: Fisher and Ury's rule: focus on interests, not positions. Positions clash. Interests can align.

twist.text: Asking why do you want that? often reveals a shared goal buried under the disagreement.

climax.text: Reframe: we both want X. Now how do we get there in a way that works for both of us?

punchline.text: Dig past positions. The common ground is underneath.

quiz.question: What is the key insight from Fisher and Ury about resolving conflict?
options: Focus on underlying interests, not stated positions
Always find a compromise that splits the difference equally
Whoever has the stronger position should win the argument
